paragraphs: I’ve learned over time that words matter and are very powerful!

Some of the words that have impacted me the most have been from people that I have great respect for because of their life experience and their example to me.  My grandfather James Russel Hazzard didn’t always speak (he was quiet and mostly listened) but when he spoke we would all listen closely. Grandpa Hazzard said very little to me about my journey as a pastor, but what he did say dramatically shaped my journey as a pastor.

The sobering reality of this text is that the thessalonians were suffering for their message and belief in Jesus Christ but they were growing and living in a way that honoured Christ and pleased God.
Pastor Phil Hazzard

body.title: SURPRISE
paragraphs: Do you like surprises?  For many children (and adults) they love to be surprised!  Surprise gifts, surprise parties, and surprise treats, these can bring joy to people and make them happy. But some surprises are not always good.  An unexpected mark, some bad news from the doctor, or an unforeseen household expense can come as a surprise but not a good one.  Both the good surprises and the bad surprises are going to happen to us in life.  It is easier for us to see God working in the good surprises, but is God still involved in our lives when the bad surprises come?

In 1 Thessalonians chapter three Paul gets a big surprise.  He was forced to leave Thessalonica because of intense persecution.  It was tough to be a Christ follower in this city and Christians were treated badly.  Paul loved these people and he was sad to leave. He was worried that they would not grow in their walk with God because of the intense persecution.  But then he heard from his friend Timothy that even though the Christians were being persecuted, the people were growing in faith and love!  What a surprise!

Some surprises in life are good, and some are bad, but in both we can still grow in our faith and learn to hear from God. There might be tough times, but we can be open to God surprising us just like he surprised Paul!
Pastor Kathy Mead

Growing is inevitable.  We all do it, naturally.

In this portion of scripture the Thessalonian Church is being praised for growing in their faith in Jesus Christ. This is true evidence that someone is growing up in their faith in Jesus Christ.  Our love for one another should always grow and look like the love that God has for us in Jesus Christ.  Forgiving.  Treating one another as we would want to be treated ourselves.  Patient and gracious.

Pastor Phil Hazzard

paragraphs: When you have been a Christian for a number of years, there are certain topics that are talked about a lot that die down for a certain time and then pop up again.A common one is the topic and teachings around the end times.

I can still remember  watching movies in youth group about the end days and seeing people having the mark of the beast tattooed on their forehead (very scary!).  I remember how people believed the end of the world was going to happen when the clock struck midnight on December 31st in 1999 when we moved into the new century.

More recently, I have once again had conversations with people who think we are in the last days because of the global pandemic and global lockdowns. As someone who did not grow up in a Christian home, I was always baffled by these discussions and the fears that came.  I believed that we should just put our trust in God to handle all of these matters and that if we are children of God, we do not need to fear.  This is what Paul teaches us in 2 Thessalonians.

Paul is speaking against false teaching that is being spread about Jesus’ return and is reminding the Church that thinking about our future, even the end times, should not cause panic. Instead it should cause joy since we will experience God’s glory (vs 14).  This is a great reminder for us as well. Let’s have hope about the future, stand firm and not be afraid!  End times or not, as Christians we can put our trust in Jesus knowing that in the end, we will get to be with Him forever!
Pastor Kathy Mead

verses.6: In the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, we command you, brothers, to keep away from every brother who is idle and does not live according to the teaching you received from us.

verses.12: Such people we command and urge in the Lord Jesus Christ to settle down and earn the bread they eat.
verses.13: And as for you, brothers, never tire of doing what is right.
verses.14: If anyone does not obey our instruction in this letter, take special note of him. Do not associate with him, in order that he may feel ashamed.
verses.15: Yet do not regard him as an enemy, but warn him as a brother.

paragraphs: Laziness is when we know we should do something, but we don’t want to, and come up with excuses. Sometimes we even spend more energy defending our laziness than had we just done the chore! Maybe we don’t want to do it because we don’t know how or its inconvenient or we’ve procrastinated. But whatever the reason, we can feel tempted to be lazy. We mow the lawn, kind of. Or we clean up our room by shoving it all in the closet. But the problem is that when we do this, we actually end up making more work for us or someone else later.

God honours hard work, and he also asks us to rest. What he doesn’t do is allow us to be lazy. When we work hard, we tell God and others that they matter. When we get lazy, we tell God and others that we matter more.
Pastor Andrew Brown

Sometimes we even spend more energy defending our laziness than had we just done the chore! Maybe we don’t want to do it because we don’t know how or its inconvenient or we’ve procrastinated. But whatever the reason, we can feel tempted to be lazy. We mow the lawn, kind of. Or we clean up our room by shoving it all in the closet. But the problem is that when we do this, we actually end up making more work for us or someone else later.

God honours hard work, and he also asks us to rest. What he doesn’t do is allow us to be lazy. When we work hard, we tell God and others that they matter. When we get lazy, we tell God and others that we matter more.
Pastor Andrew Brown

body.title: FAMILY DISCUSSION QUESTIONS
questions: What are some things that you are lazy at? What are some things you work really hard at?
Why do you think God honours hard work over laziness?
Is working hard at your walk with God harder or easier than doing other things in your week? Why?
Is there anything you can do, or your family can do, to help you when you are tempted to be lazy or take the easy way out?
